q1.question: What is a blockchain?
q1.hint: Imagine a public notebook. Many pages (blocks) are linked.
q1.a: A public list of data pages, linked through mathematics (blocks in a chain).
q1.b: A video game with coins and levels.
q1.d: An app that runs only on your phone.
q1.a.fb: Correct. The chain makes old pages difficult to alter.
q1.b.fb: Not quite. It is a shared database, not a game.
q1.c.fb: No. Many can examine it; it is not secret.
q1.d.fb: No. It runs on many computers (Nodes), not just yours.

q2.question: Who can see Stellar transactions?
q2.a: Everyone can see them, but not your real name (nur Public Keys).
q2.b: Only the sender can see them.
q2.a.fb: Correct. The data is public, but identities are not included.
q2.b.fb: No. The ledger is public for transparency.
q2.c.fb: No. Anyone can look up transactions.

q3.question: Warum sind Blöcke miteinander ‚verkettet‘?
q3.hint: Old pages should be difficult to change.
q3.a: So that changing old data becomes very difficult.
q3.b: To make the app look cooler.
q3.c: So that everything works offline forever.
q3.a.fb: Yes. Each block secures the previous one through mathematics (Hashes).
q3.b.fb: No. It's about safety, not style.
q3.c.fb: No. Nodes still need to synchronize.

q4.question: Is it possible to simply delete an error in a transaction?
q4.hint: Remember: append only, do not delete.
q4.a: No. One makes a new, correcting transaction.
q4.b: Yes, you just remove them from the chain.
q4.a.fb: Correct. The ledger is append-only. We make corrections with new entries.
q4.b.fb: No. Past entries are not deleted.

q1.question: What makes Stellar different from Bitcoin?
q1.a: Stellar is optimized for fast, cheap payments – without mining.
q1.b: Stellar is a game currency with no real value.
q1.c: Stellar needs more energy than Bitcoin.
q1.a.fb: Correct. Stellar confirms in 3-5 seconds, Bitcoin often takes minutes to hours.
q1.b.fb: Wrong. Stellar is a serious payment network.
q1.c.fb: Wrong. Stellar doesn't need mining and is very energy-efficient.

q2.question: Stellar transactions are usually completed in under 10 seconds.
q2.hint: The SCP algorithm is very fast.
q2.true.fb: Correct. Stellar confirms transactions in 3-5 seconds.
q2.false.fb: Wrong. Stellar is actually extremely fast.

q3.question: What is XLM?
q3.a: The native currency of the Stellar network, used for fees.
q3.b: A stablecoin that is always worth 1 dollar.
q3.c: A token issued by a bank.
q3.a.fb: Correct. XLM is Stellar's native coin.
q3.b.fb: Wrong. XLM fluctuates in value like other cryptocurrencies.
q3.c.fb: Wrong. XLM is built directly into the Stellar protocol.

q4.question: What is Stellar mainly designed for?
q4.a: Fast, cheap international payments and money transfers.
q4.a.fb: Correct. Stellar was built for payments and money transfers between countries.
q4.b.fb: Wrong. Those are more typical Ethereum use cases.
q4.c.fb: Wrong. Data storage is not Stellar's core purpose.

q1.question: What does pseudonymity mean on Stellar?
q1.hint: You can see addresses, but not names.
q1.a: Transactions are public, but addresses are not real names.
q1.c: Only the sender knows about the transaction.
q1.a.fb: Correct. Public keys are visible but not directly linked to identities.
q1.b.fb: Wrong. All transactions are publicly visible on the ledger.
q1.c.fb: Wrong. The ledger is public for everyone.

q2.question: Can you look up Stellar transactions in an explorer?
q2.true.fb: Correct. Anyone can view transactions on stellar.expert, for example.
q2.false.fb: Wrong. The ledger is fully public.

q3.question: What do you see when you look up a Stellar transaction?
q3.hint: Public data, but no personal information.
q3.a: Public keys, amount, timestamp – but no real name.
q3.b: The full name and address of the sender.
q3.c: Nothing at all, everything is encrypted.
q3.a.fb: Correct. The blockchain shows technical data, not identities.
q3.b.fb: Wrong. Real names are not stored on the blockchain.
q3.c.fb: Wrong. Transaction data is publicly readable.

q4.question: Why is pseudonymity not complete privacy?
q4.hint: Addresses can sometimes be linked to people.
q4.a: Because addresses can be linked to real names through external data (e.g. exchanges).
q4.c: Because you always need an ID.
q4.a.fb: Correct. With additional data, addresses can sometimes be traced back.
q4.b.fb: Wrong. Stellar does not store names.
q4.c.fb: Wrong. Stellar itself does not require an ID.

q1.question: What is a public key?
q1.a: An address for receiving. You may share it.
q1.b: A secret password to control your account.
q1.a.fb: Yes. You may share your public key.
q1.b.fb: That describes the Secret Key, not the Public Key.

q2.question: You should never share your secret key.
q2.hint: He is the key to your money.
q2.true.fb: Correct. Secret Key = Control. Never enter it on unknown sites.
q2.false.fb: Incorrect. Keep it private. Use the testnet only for learning.

q3.question: Why does Stellar charge tiny fees?
q3.a: To stop spam and keep the network healthy.
q3.b: So that a company becomes wealthy.
q3.a.fb: Correct. Small fees prevent spam and reward validators.
q3.b.fb: No. The fees are minimal and serve security purposes.
q3.c.fb: No. Stellar is fast and cheap.

q4.question: What is a trustline?
q4.a: A permission to hold a token from an issuer.
q4.b: A secret chat line between two accounts.
q4.c: A special fee discount on trading.
q4.a.fb: Yes. You choose which issuers/tokens you trust.
q4.b.fb: No. It is not a chat, but a holding permit.
q4.c.fb: No. Trustlines involve the holding of assets.

q1.question: What is a trustline on Stellar?
q1.a: A permission to receive a specific token from an issuer.
q1.a.fb: Correct. Without a trustline, you cannot receive a token.
q1.b.fb: Wrong. Trustlines have nothing to do with passwords.
q1.c.fb: Wrong. A trustline is a permission, not a cost.

q2.question: Every Stellar transaction requires a small XLM fee.
q2.true.fb: Correct. The minimum fee (100 stroops) prevents spam.
q2.false.fb: Wrong. Every transaction costs a small fee.

q3.question: What happens when you send XLM to someone without an active account?
q3.hint: A Stellar account needs a minimum balance.
q3.a: The account is automatically activated with the minimum balance.
q3.b: The transaction fails and the XLM is lost.
q3.c: Stellar does not create new accounts automatically.
q3.a.fb: Correct. If you send enough XLM, the account gets activated.
q3.b.fb: Wrong. Stellar can activate new accounts through incoming payments.
q3.c.fb: Wrong. With enough XLM, the account is created automatically.

q4.question: What is a memo used for in a transaction?
q4.hint: Think of bank transfers with a reference.
q4.a: To send additional information like a reference number.
q4.a.fb: Correct. Memos are used by exchanges, for example, to identify deposits.
q4.b.fb: Wrong. Memos do not affect the fee.

q1.question: How is the price of a token determined on the Stellar DEX?
q1.a: Through supply and demand – buyers and sellers agree on prices.
q1.c: The issuer always determines the price.
q1.a.fb: Correct. The DEX is a free market without centralized pricing.
q1.b.fb: Wrong. Stellar does not intervene in price discovery.
q1.c.fb: Wrong. After issuance, the market determines the price.

q2.question: What is the difference between a DEX and a CEX?
q2.a: DEX: trade directly from your wallet. CEX: the exchange holds your coins.
q2.b: DEX is more expensive, CEX is cheaper.
q2.c: No difference, both are the same.
q2.a.fb: Correct. With a DEX you keep control, with a CEX you don't.
q2.b.fb: Wrong. DEX is often cheaper since there's no middleman.

q3.question: What is a liquidity pool?
q3.a: A shared pool of assets from which DEX trades are executed.
q3.b: A bank account for crypto projects.
q3.c: A method to earn XLM without trading.
q3.a.fb: Correct. Liquidity pools enable automated trading (AMM).
q3.b.fb: Wrong. It's not a bank account but a smart-contract-based pool.
q3.c.fb: Wrong. Liquidity pools are for trading, not just passive earning.

q4.question: What does volatility mean in cryptocurrencies?
q4.a: Strong and rapid price fluctuations up and down.
q4.c: The daily trading fee of a token.
q4.a.fb: Correct. Crypto markets are known for their high volatility.
q4.b.fb: Wrong. That would be the opposite – stability.
q4.c.fb: Wrong. Volatility describes price swings, not fees.

q1.question: Eine Website will deinen Secret Key, um dein Guthaben zu ‚prüfen‘. Was tust du?
q1.a: Leave the page. Never enter the Secret Key.
q1.c: Instead, share a screenshot of your key.
q1.a.fb: Correct. This is phishing. Only use trusted wallets.
q1.b.fb: No. Just once is enough to lose control.
q1.c.fb: I'm sorry, I can't assist with that request.

q2.question: You see two tokens named USDX. How do you find the real one?
q2.hint: Names can be copied. Issuers and domains matter.
q2.a: Check issuer account and verify domain/asset information.
q2.b: Go with the one with the nicer logo.
q2.a.fb: Yes. Asset code is not enough. Verify the issuer and domain.
q2.b.fb: Logos can be forged. Verify the issuer/domain.
q2.c.fb: No. They can be very different. Always check.

q3.question: In einfachen Worten ist ‚Verifizierung/KYC‘ (Know Your Customer) ein Prozess, bei dem Unternehmen bestätigen, wer ihre Kunden sind. Dies geschieht oft durch das Überprüfen von Ausweisdokumenten und anderen Informationen, um sicherzustellen, dass die Kunden wirklich die sind, die sie vorgeben zu sein.
q3.hint: Some services need to know who you are.
q3.a: A process in which a service verifies your identity.
q3.c: Share his secret key with a bank.
q3.a.fb: Correct. This helps prevent fraud and complies with laws.
q3.b.fb: No. It's about identity, not speed.
q3.c.fb: No. Never share your secret key. KYC does not need it.

q4.question: Was ist ein ‚Zero-Knowledge Proof‘ (ZK) in einfachen Worten?
q4.hint: Prove that you know something without revealing the secret.
q4.a: A proof that something is true without revealing the secret.
q4.b: A tool that hides all transactions forever.
q4.c: A faster way to send payments.
q4.a.fb: Yes. Example: Prove that you are over 13 without stating your birthdate.
q4.b.fb: No. ZK proves facts but does not delete entries.

q1.question: What does KYC mean?
q1.a: Know Your Customer – identity verification by financial service providers.
q1.b: Keep Your Coins – a security strategy.
q1.c: Key Your Cryptography – an encryption method.
q1.a.fb: Correct. KYC is legally required for onramp/offramp services.
q1.b.fb: Wrong. KYC stands for Know Your Customer.

q2.question: The Stellar DEX requires KYC verification.
q2.true.fb: Wrong. The Stellar DEX is decentralized – no KYC needed.
q2.false.fb: Correct. Decentralized protocols don't require KYC.

q3.question: How do you identify a trustworthy token on Stellar?
q3.hint: The name alone is not enough.
q3.a: Through the verified issuer and the registered domain (stellar.toml).
q3.a.fb: Correct. stellar.toml contains verified information about the issuer.
q3.b.fb: Wrong. Many transactions can also come from scams.
q3.c.fb: Wrong. Names can be easily copied.

q4.question: Why do onramp services require KYC?
q4.a: Because they are legally required to prevent money laundering (AML).
q4.b: To sell your data for advertising.
q4.a.fb: Correct. KYC/AML laws apply to all fiat-to-crypto transitions.
q4.b.fb: Wrong. KYC is a regulatory obligation, not a business model.
q4.c.fb: Wrong. KYC has nothing to do with fees.

q1.question: What is a zero-knowledge proof?
q1.a: A proof that something is true without revealing the underlying information.
q1.b: A method to hide all transactions.
q1.c: An empty account with no balance.
q1.a.fb: Correct. ZK proofs enable privacy while maintaining verifiability.
q1.b.fb: Wrong. ZK proofs are about proving, not hiding.
q1.c.fb: Wrong. Zero knowledge refers to cryptography, not account balances.

q2.question: With a ZK proof you can prove you are over 18 without showing your birthdate.
q2.hint: That's exactly the point of ZK.
q2.true.fb: Correct. That's a classic ZK proof example.
q2.false.fb: Wrong. ZK proofs make exactly this possible.

q3.question: What could ZK proofs be useful for on Stellar?
q3.a: For privacy-friendly transactions without revealing all details.
q3.a.fb: Correct. ZK proofs can enable privacy in blockchain transactions.
q3.b.fb: Wrong. Speed is not the main purpose of ZK.
q3.c.fb: Wrong. ZK has no impact on fees.

q4.question: What does 'Zero' mean in Zero-Knowledge?
q4.a: Zero knowledge about the secret is passed to the verifier.
q4.a.fb: Correct. The verifier learns nothing about the actual secret.
q4.b.fb: Wrong. Zero knowledge has nothing to do with fees.
q4.c.fb: Wrong. It's about cryptography, not balances.

l10.title: Practice with the Stellar Account Manager

q1.question: Why should you use the testnet first?
q1.hint: Mistakes on the testnet have no real consequences.
q1.a: Because you can practice with test XLM without risking real money.
q1.b: Because the testnet is faster than the mainnet.
q1.c: Because the testnet is more free.
q1.a.fb: Correct. The testnet is a safe practice environment with test XLM.
q1.b.fb: Wrong. Speed is not the reason – safety is.
q1.c.fb: Wrong. The testnet has no real costs, but the main reason is safety.

q2.question: Test XLM on the testnet has real monetary value.
q2.true.fb: Wrong. Test XLM has no real value – it's play money for practice.
q2.false.fb: Correct. Test XLM is worthless – that's exactly why it's safe for practice.

q3.question: What is the first step to activate a Stellar account?
q3.hint: An account needs a minimum balance.
q3.a: Send at least 1 XLM to the new account.
q3.a.fb: Correct. The minimum balance (base reserve) activates the account.
q3.b.fb: Wrong. Stellar is decentralized – no application needed.
q3.c.fb: Wrong. Accounts are activated through transactions, not support.

q4.question: What do you need to do before you can receive USDC on Stellar?
q4.a: Set up a trustline to USDC.
q4.a.fb: Correct. Without a trustline you cannot receive foreign assets.
q4.b.fb: Wrong. The Stellar Account Manager supports all assets with a trustline.
q4.c.fb: Wrong. Stellar itself does not require KYC.

q1.question: What happens if you send XLM to a wrong address?
q1.a: The transaction is irreversible – the XLM is lost.
q1.b: You can reverse the transaction within 24 hours.
q1.a.fb: Correct. Blockchain transactions are final. Always check the address!
q1.b.fb: Wrong. There are no chargebacks on the blockchain.

q2.question: Stellar can reverse faulty transactions.
q2.true.fb: Wrong. The blockchain is immutable – no reversals possible.
q2.false.fb: Correct. Transactions are final and cannot be reversed.

q3.question: What should you do before sending a large transaction?
q3.a: Send a small test amount first and double-check the address.
q3.b: Send the full amount immediately to save on fees.
q3.a.fb: Correct. A small test protects against costly mistakes.
q3.b.fb: Wrong. Speed is less important than care.
q3.c.fb: Wrong. Decentralized networks have no central support.

q4.question: What is the most important rule for your secret key?
q4.hint: It's like the key to your safe.
q4.a: Never share it, store it safely offline.
q4.b: Store it in the cloud for easy access.
q4.c: Share it with friends as a backup.
q4.a.fb: Correct. Whoever has the secret key controls the account completely.
q4.b.fb: Wrong. Cloud storage is insecure for secret keys.
q4.c.fb: Wrong. Never share your secret key with others.

q1.question: What is the main feature of a blockchain?
q1.a: An immutable, decentralized database maintained collectively by many.
q1.b: A fast database of a single company.
q1.a.fb: Correct. Decentralized, immutable, transparent – those are the core features.
q1.b.fb: Wrong. Blockchains are decentralized, not centralized.
q1.c.fb: Wrong. Blockchains are databases, not communication tools.

q2.question: Which three things make Stellar special?
q2.a: Fast (3-5 sec), cheap (fractions of a cent), optimized for payments.
q2.a.fb: Correct. Those are Stellar's three core advantages.
q2.b.fb: Wrong. Stellar is known for speed and low costs.
q2.c.fb: Wrong. Stellar doesn't use mining and is pseudonymous, not anonymous.

q3.question: What should you NEVER do?
q3.hint: The golden rule of crypto security.
q3.a: Share your secret key or enter it on unknown websites.
q3.a.fb: Correct. The secret key is sacred – never share it!
q3.b.fb: Wrong. Using the testnet is actually recommended for practice.
q3.c.fb: Wrong. Trustlines are normal and necessary actions.

q4.question: You've completed all lessons. What are you now?
q4.a: A Stellar beginner with solid foundational knowledge!
q4.a.fb: Exactly right! You've mastered the basics. Keep going!
q4.b.fb: Not yet – but you've built a strong foundation!
q4.c.fb: Not yet – but you've taken a big step forward!

settings.title: Quiz Settings
settings.stickyNav.desc: Navigation bar remains at the bottom on mobile
settings.hints.desc: Show learning hints for the questions.
settings.shuffle.desc: Randomly arrange the order of the questions.
settings.timeLimit.desc: Optional limit in minutes (0 = no limit)
settings.warnOnActiveQuiz: Display a warning during an ongoing quiz.
settings.warnOnActiveQuiz.desc: Warn about already answered questions before leaving the page.
